newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Belgrade bourse turnover up in week ending Sep 27.
newsitem.headline: Belgrade bourse turnover up in week ending Sep 27.

text.p: The Belgrade Stock Exchange (BSE) on Monday reported a slight 2.91 percent rise in its turnover for the week ending September 27 but traders said reduced liquidity was still slowing down the market.
The BSE weekly turnover rose to 37.93 million dinars ($7.58 million) from 36.856 in the previous week, the bourse said in its report. The number of transactions soared to 185 from 145.
"Overall lack of funds resulting from the recently launched 10 percent reserve requirement weighs on market activity and there is no improvement in sight," a trader told Reuters.
One Belgrade analyst, who asked not to be named, said the central bank's measure effectively limited the money supply by forcing plenty of cash out of circulation.
Another market analyst said the central bank signalled it wanted only healthy banks to survive.
In the meantime, the bourse continues its rather slack performance with the commercial paper segment taking a lead with 157 deals worth 18.874 million dinars.
Interest rates on commercial paper kept their range between an annual 44 and 520 percent.
Central bank short-term bonds were traded five times for a volume of 15.250 million dinars.
Treasury bills generated 3.256 million dinars in 21 deals, the BSE's report said.
Earlier announcements by the government of Serbia to fund 1997 wheat sowing with a new issue of wheat selling forward contracts could give a boost to the lacklustre market, a trader said.
